Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[Stats] Ingest Microsoft CDN logs alongside Verizon CDN logs" (#8376) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody: Make gallery changes to allow multiple specified locations for downloads statistics.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Improved the #r directive instructions" (#8481) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
This issue is to track pull request: https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/pull/8405
 
This is a follow up to #8375

Since #r is not exclusive to F#, it is a bit inaccurate to use the current header for the instructions - it would make sense to use a more generic name for it.
Therefore I propose to rename F# Interactive to .NET Interactive as it then correctly captures both C# and F#.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "NuGet.org outage work-arounds" (#8480) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody: Here is where the team will post and discuss work-arounds for the current NuGet.org outage.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Clarify that the the statistics page only shows recent downloads" (#8479) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Describe the bug

It's not clear that the table in the package downloads page shows downloads for the last 6 weeks:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/737941/113358201-3266a880-92fa-11eb-90e2-2e23a73235fd.png)

We should update the table's heading to `Downloads (last 6 weeks)`

Reported by: https://twitter.com/Tyrrrz/status/1377717292176445455?s=20

Events.RelatedBody:
Summary of the changes (in less than 80 characters):

I reverted(https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/pull/8470) previous PR. 
This one intend to be in **DEV**


Same PR https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/pull/8464

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "[Stats]Faster stats refresh" (#8478) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Small change to speed up the stats refresh since pipeline updates should allow the report to generate fast enough for this.

In theory, this will quadruple the hits on storage through this, and performance impact of this has not been analyzed.
However, I do not expect the impact of hitting 6 files 4 times instead of once every hour to be major.

This is not a critical change for functionality, and I'm happy to defer it if we so desire.

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "[Statistics]Adding Support for other reports from alternate container" (#8472) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Adds support for sourcing other reports from the alternate stats container.
Currently, feature flagging is all-or-nothing.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Stats]Update DI to use Attributes instead of Keyed Resolution" (#8477) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody: See https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/pull/8472#discussion_r604587154 for location and suggestion

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Implement maccatalyst warning when "falling back" to xamarin.ios for net6.0+ projects" (#10718) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
As part of net6.0's [new precedence rules](https://github.com/dotnet/designs/blob/main/accepted/2021/net6.0-tfms/net6.0-tfms.md#compatibility-rules) (see #10717), we're adding a warning so that when xamarin.ios is picked for net6.0+ projects, we raise a warning informing customers of what we did.

As part of this task, we need to come up with a good warning message, and a new warning code, and run it by PM to make sure it's the right thing.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Implement new precedence for xamarin TFMs when using net6.0+" (#10717) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody: As part of net6.0, we're implementing [new compatibility rules for xamarin TFMs](https://github.com/dotnet/designs/blob/main/accepted/2021/net6.0-tfms/net6.0-tfms.md#compatibility-rules). This is a tracking issue for implementing the precedence part of it.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Move CLI exception messages to String Resource files" (#10392) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
There are some hard-coded strings in Exception messages for the CLI.
After some PR discussion, it seems we should create localized strings for these: https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/pull/3799#discussion_r544749207

Example:

> '{0}' is not a valid version string.

https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/blob/dev/src/NuGet.Clients/NuGet.VisualStudio/LegacyTypes/SemanticVersion.cs#L146

I believe this one comes up for folks quite a lot, but there's probably quite a few more than this one.
/cc @dominoFire

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "DirectoryNotFoundException in PackTask PathResolver" (#10716) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
<!-- Please read the following information before posting the issue. -->
<!-- If you're having trouble with the NuGet client tools (the Visual Studio extension, NuGet.exe command line tool, etc.), you are in the right place. -->
<!-- If you're having trouble with the NuGet.org Website, please post in [NuGetGallery issues](http://github.com/nuget/nugetgallery/issues) -->

## Details about Problem

NuGet product used: dotnet.exe

Product version: 5.0.201

## Repro steps and/or sample project

I'm relatively new to nuget package creation.  I'm attempting to pack a .NET Standard project with 3rd party .NET Framework dll dependencies.
csproj:
`<Project Sdk="Microsoft.NET.Sdk">
  <PropertyGroup>
    <TargetFrameworks>netstandard2.0;net472</TargetFrameworks>
    <PackageTags>Laserfiche SEA ESI "Texas A&M"</PackageTags>
    <GeneratePackageOnBuild>true</GeneratePackageOnBuild>
    <version>1.0.1.5</version>
    <AssemblyVersion>1.0.0.0</AssemblyVersion>
    <FileVersion>1.0.1.5</FileVersion>
    <Company>Texas A&M System Offices</Company>
    <RunPostBuildEvent>OnBuildSuccess</RunPostBuildEvent>
    <!--<IncludeSymbols>true</IncludeSymbols>-->
    <SymbolPackageFormat>snupkg</SymbolPackageFormat>
    <PackageRequireLicenseAcceptance>false</PackageRequireLicenseAcceptance>
    <AutoGenerateBindingRedirects>true</AutoGenerateBindingRedirects>
    <NuspecFile>SEALaserfiche.nuspec</NuspecFile>
  </PropertyGroup>`

SEALaserfiche.nuspec:
`<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8" ?>
<package xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/packaging/2013/05/nuspec.xsd">
  <metadata>
    <id>SEALaserfiche</id>
    <version>1.0.1.5</version>
    <authors>Andrew Beehler</authors>
    <description>Test</description>
    <copyright>Test</copyright>
    <dependencies>
      <group targetFramework=".NETFramework4.7.2" />
      <group targetFramework=".NETStandard2.0" />
    </dependencies>
  </metadata>
  <files>
    <file src="bin\$config$\netstandard2.0\*.dll" target="lib\netstandard2.0\" />
    <file src="bin\$config$\net472\*.dll" target="lib\net472\" />
  </files>
</package>`

I attempt to run the following command:
`dotnet pack -p:config=debug`

...and get this error: "C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk\5.0.201\Sdks\NuGet.Build.Tasks.Pack\buildCrossTargeting\NuGet.Build.Tasks.Pack.targets(221,5): error : Could not find a part of the path 'C:\esi\CommonClasses\SEALaserfiche\SEALaserfiche_DEV\SEALaserfiche\bin\netstandard2.0'."

not sure why it's not looking in "\bin\debug\netstandard2.0"

### Verbose Logs

Here's the section of the output we're probably interested in.  shows the stack trace.  tried going through nuget code on github.  have not yet been able to determine where the "\bin\netstandard2.0" is coming from; why it doesn't have "\debug\" in the path.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "NuGet.Client build.sh is broken" (#10139) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
`./build.sh` fails when trying to install .NET Core 1.1:
```
$ ./build.sh 
Installing dotnet CLI
  % Total    % Received % Xferd  Average Speed   Time    Time     Time  Current
                                 Dload  Upload   Total   Spent    Left  Speed

100 34939  100 34939    0     0  85425      0 --:--:-- --:--:-- --:--:--  541k
dotnet_install: Warning: Unable to locate zlib. Probable prerequisite missing; install zlib.
dotnet-install: Downloading link: https://dotnetcli.azureedge.net/dotnet/Sdk/1.1.11/dotnet-sdk-1.1.11-linux-x64.tar.gz
curl: (22) The requested URL returned error: 404 
dotnet-install: Cannot download: https://dotnetcli.azureedge.net/dotnet/Sdk/1.1.11/dotnet-sdk-1.1.11-linux-x64.tar.gz
dotnet_install: Error: Could not find/download: `.NET Core SDK` with version = 1.1.11
dotnet_install: Error: Refer to: https://aka.ms/dotnet-os-lifecycle for information on .NET Core support
```

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Local Build fails when Build encounters an RSP (response) file" (#9973) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about the Problem

Repository: [NuGet.Client](/NuGet/NuGet.Client)

When building locally, the common.ps1 script will fail when it encounters a response file like `Directory.Buil.rsp` within or above the repo folder. The reason is that the script gets the .NET SDK version through MSBuild text output but when the response file is detected, MSBuild spews out a header text for the response file and that messes up with the logic for getting the .NET SDK version.

## Detailed repro steps

1. Go to your local NuGet.Client repo

2. Clean your local repo with `git clean -Xdf`

3. Add a `Directory.Buil.rsp` file within or above the repo folder

4. Run configure.ps1 and see that'll fail.

## Other suggested things

### Verbose Logs

```console
PS E:\Projects\Microsoft.NET\nuget-client> .\configure.ps1
[16:20:08 +0]   Configuring NuGet.Client build environment
[16:20:08 +0]   [BEGIN] Configuring git repo
[16:20:08 +0]   [DONE +00:00:00] Configuring git repo
[16:20:08 +0]   [BEGIN] Installing .NET CLI
[16:20:09 +1]   Downloading .NET CLI
[16:20:09 +0]   The version of SDK should be installed is : command
[16:20:09 +0]   Probing folder : E:\Projects\Microsoft.NET\nuget-client\cli\sdk\command
dotnet-install: Downloading link: https://dotnetcli.azureedge.net/dotnet/Sdk/command/dotnet-sdk-command-win-x64.zip
dotnet-install: Cannot download: https://dotnetcli.azureedge.net/dotnet/Sdk/command/dotnet-sdk-command-win-x64.zip
dotnet-install: Downloading legacy link: https://dotnetcli.azureedge.net/dotnet/Sdk/command/dotnet-dev-win-x64.command.zip
dotnet-install: Cannot download: https://dotnetcli.azureedge.net/dotnet/Sdk/command/dotnet-dev-win-x64.command.zip
Error-Log : [16:20:16 +7]       [FAILED +00:00:08] Installing .NET CLI
At E:\Projects\Microsoft.NET\nuget-client\build\common.ps1:122 char:17
+ ...             Error-Log "[FAILED +$(Format-ElapsedTime $sw.Elapsed)] $B ...
+                 ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
    + CategoryInfo          : NotSpecified: (:) [Write-Error], WriteErrorException
    + FullyQualifiedErrorId : Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.WriteErrorException,Error-Log

Could not find/download: ".NET Core SDK" with version = command
Refer to: https://aka.ms/dotnet-os-lifecycle for information on .NET Core support
At E:\Projects\Microsoft.NET\nuget-client\cli\dotnet-install.ps1:660 char:5
+     throw "Could not find/download: `"$assetName`" with version = $Sp ...
+     ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
    + CategoryInfo          : OperationStopped: (Could not find/...ET Core support:String) [], RuntimeException
    + FullyQualifiedErrorId : Could not find/download: ".NET Core SDK" with version = command
Refer to: https://aka.ms/dotnet-os-lifecycle for information on .NET Core support
```

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "NuGet.exe pack performance problem with `..` relative path" (#5016) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Description
I'm NuGet packing our JavaScript application for Octopus Deploy to deploy to a test server. All content in the *unbundled* app creates a 40 MB NuGet package including ~8000 files. This was never a problem, as with 3.5.0 packing the app was quite quick. After upgrading to Visual Studio 2017 and NuGet 4.1.0, our build server started failing on the packaging step since it timeouts after 5 minutes. While trying to reproduce this, I found out that the timeout occurs only when using a `..` relative path for including files.

## Example
Packing the same `.nuspec` file from the command line produces these results:
### NuGet.exe 3.5.0 vs NuGet.exe 4.1.0
```
PS {~\D\e\n\script> .\repro.ps1

Wednesday 12. April 2017 12.44.58
Attempting to build package from 'nuget-performance-test.nuspec'.
Successfully created package
'C:\Users\Jussi\Documents\edit-temp\nuget_perf_repro\script\NuGet.Performance.Test.3.5.0.nupkg'.
Wednesay 12. April  2017 12.45.00
Attempting to build package from 'nuget-performance-test.nuspec'.
Successfully created package
'C:\Users\Jussi\Documents\edit-temp\nuget_perf_repro\script\NuGet.Performance.Test.4.1.0.nupkg'.
Wednesay 12. April  2017 12.45.34
```
## Example results
**With 3.5.0**, packing the app took **~2 seconds.**
**With 4.1.0**, packing the app took **~34 seconds.**

## On an actual project
With our actual application, the difference looks like this on the build server:
**With 3.5.0**, packing the app took **~20 seconds.**
**With 4.1.0**, packing the app took **~9 minutes.**

## Details about Problem
NuGet product used (NuGet.exe | VS UI | Package Manager Console | dotnet.exe):
NuGet.Exe

NuGet version (x.x.x.xxx):
4.1.0.2450

OS version:
Windows 10 Version 1607 (OS Build 14393.953)
Windows Server 2016 Datacenter Version 1607 (OS Build 14393.969)

Worked before? If so, with which NuGet version:
3.5.0.1938

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem
1. Create a new SPA application, using e.g. [Aurelia](https://aurelia.io), that depends on a huge amount of NPM packages that need to be deployed with the application.
2. Create a `.nuspec` file, including all files from for the *unbundled* SPA application using a path starting with `..`. This should include a large amount of small JS files.
3. Pack with NuGet 3.5.0 and 4.1.0 and compare time spent packing.

## Other suggested things
- Small number of files to pack hides the issue.
- The issue doesn't happen when the include path doesn't start with `..`. That is:
`<file src="..\app\wwwroot\**\*.*" target="" />` will show the error but with 
`<file src="wwwroot\**\*.*" target="" />`, I was unable to reproduce the problem.

## Workaround
Copy the files in a folder below the `.nuspec` file and include from there.

### Verbose Logs
There's nothing special in the verbose logs, packing succeeds but just takes a lot of time on 4.1.0.

### Sample Project
There's a Powershell script (`repro.ps1`)in this package to demonstrate the issue:
https://1drv.ms/u/s!ArvtSAxE-8DWitlqmMKfjzzFB94_Gw

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Speculative bug] Ensure all code paths work with a download count exceeding int.MaxValue" (#10715) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
<!-- Please read the following information before posting the issue. -->
<!-- If you're having trouble with the NuGet client tools (the Visual Studio extension, NuGet.exe command line tool, etc.), you are in the right place. -->
<!-- If you're having trouble with the NuGet.org Website, please post in [NuGetGallery issues](http://github.com/nuget/nugetgallery/issues) -->

## Details about Problem

NuGet product used: all
Product version: latest

## Repro steps and/or sample project

See https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/8476. In short, sooner or later Newtonsoft.Json will exceed `int.MaxValue` (2,147,483,647) as may cause problems.

End-to-end, we (NuGet team) need to ensure that a download count exceeding `int.MaxValue` does not break the client. The aforementioned link tracks the server-side investigation/fixes.

I have confirmed the following with Fiddler on client side.

- PM UI Browse tab, V3 nuget.org
  - âœ”ï¸ Works up to 1000 trillion (so we have plenty of runway ðŸ˜„)
  - ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/94054/113341530-1eaf4800-92e2-11eb-9793-1d53f5372c23.png)
  - âŒ Crashes VS after 1000 trillion
- PM UI Browse tab, V2 nuget.org
  - Same as V3.
- nuget.exe search, V3 nuget.org
  - âœ”ï¸ Works up to `long.MaxValue`
  - ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/94054/113340825-3afeb500-92e1-11eb-9b47-05fe3e04ff94.png)
  - âŒ Fails over to USSC (???) after `long.MaxValue`
- nuget.exe search V2 nuget.org
  - âœ”ï¸ Works up to `long.MaxValue`
  - ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/94054/113340947-684b6300-92e1-11eb-9cbb-5a7457d521de.png)
  - âœ”ï¸ Shows N/A after `long.MaxValue` (I think this is a good behavior)
  - ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/94054/113342087-e3614900-92e2-11eb-83c5-41acdee6a8ca.png)

From this analysis it seems that client is fine for the `int.MaxValue`. However I may be missing places and I think it would be prudent to do a pass over all of the places to make sure at least `int.MaxValue + 1` doesn't crash NuGet since this is a real situation on the horizon.

I don't know all of the places download count is used on the client.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "textfile.nuspec failing to build the project after upgrading to Visual Studio 2019 16.9.1 from Version 16.8.7" (#10663) at NuGet/Home

I don't think our CI should block PRs being merged if an external resource has a service outage, or the CI agent is having flakey network access to the outside world.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "NuGet.org temporarily down due to Azure services outage" (#57) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
NuGet.org is being affected by an outage due to issues affecting the Azure Portal and Azure services, but the team is on it. We appreciate your patience and we will keep you updated as soon as we get more information.

In the meantime, check https://status2.azure.com/ for Azure updates and find work-arounds in this thread https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/8480.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Notice: NuGet Restore Failures on Linux distributions using NSS or Mozilla root CA list" (#56) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
## Context

Users of .NET 5.0+ will receive error messages when running `dotnet restore` on Linux distros that use [nss](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Mozilla/Projects/NSS/) or `ca-certificates` packages maintained by Mozilla's root CA list. The root cause is due to the certificate used for signed NuGet packages recently expiring and as a result the validation for packages uses a timestamp provider chain that has a root certificate that has been [removed by Network Security Services (NSS)](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1686854) which is a popular alternative to [OpenSSL](https://github.com/openssl/openssl).

- [NuGet Microsoft Author Signing Certificate Update](https://devblogs.microsoft.com/nuget/microsoft-author-signing-certificate-update/) - Expires January 27th, 2021
- [NuGet.org Repository Signing Certificate Update](https://devblogs.microsoft.com/nuget/the-nuget-org-repository-signing-certificate-will-be-updated-as-soon-as-march-15th-2021/) - Expires April 14th, 2021

For more information, please read the [Distrust of Symantec TLS Certificates](https://blog.mozilla.org/security/2018/03/12/distrust-symantec-tls-certificates/) on the Mozilla Security Blog, [Mozilla Root Store Policy](https://www.mozilla.org/en-US/about/governance/policies/security-group/certs/policy/) on Mozilla.org, and [Symantec Issues](https://wiki.mozilla.org/CA:Symantec_Issues) on the Mozilla Wiki Page.

## Affected Environments

.NET 5.0+ SDK on Linux distros that use [nss 3.63+](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Mozilla/Projects/NSS/NSS_3.63_release_notes). 

At this time, we are not sure of every distro that may be affected. If you're aware of an affected distro, please let us know!

Below is a table that includes .NET support for Linux distros:

### Linux

OS                                    | Version               | Affected          |
--------------------------------------|-----------------------|-------------------|
[Alpine Linux][Alpine]                | N/A                 | â“ |
[CentOS][CentOS]                      | N/A                    | â“ |
[Debian][Debian]                      | N/A                    | â“ |
[Fedora][Fedora]                      | N/A                   | â“ |
[Linux Mint][Linux-Mint]              | N/A                   | â“ |
[openSUSE][OpenSUSE]                  | N/A                   | â“ |
[Red Hat Enterprise Linux][RHEL]      | N/A                    | â“ |
[SUSE Enterprise Linux (SLES)][SLES]  | N/A               | â“ |
[Ubuntu][Ubuntu]                      | N/A   | â“ |

[Alpine]: https://alpinelinux.org/
[CentOS]: https://www.centos.org/
[Debian]: https://www.debian.org/
[Fedora]: https://getfedora.org/
[Linux-Mint]: https://linuxmint.com/
[OpenSUSE]: https://opensuse.org/
[RHEL]: https://www.redhat.com/en/technologies/linux-platforms/enterprise-linux
[SLES]: https://www.suse.com/products/server/
[Ubuntu]: https://ubuntu.com/

Additionally, here is a table of other Linux variants that may be affected but are not officially supported by .NET.

OS                                    | Version               | Affected       |
--------------------------------------|-----------------------|-------------------|
[Arch Linux](https://archlinux.org/)                          | 20210328+                 | âœ…[Issue](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/10695)             |
[Artix Linux](https://artixlinux.org/)                         | 20201128+                    | âœ…[Issue](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/10684)             |

### Other Linux distros

- At the time of writing, we believe other distributions will not be affected until a distribution is updated to include [nss 3.63+](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Mozilla/Projects/NSS/NSS_3.63_release_notes).

## Mitigation

### .NET Core 3.1

.NET 5 introduces a signing verification mechanism that promotes warnings to throw an error at `dotnet restore` time. To work around this, you can temporarily target against .NET Core 3.1.

### Modify CA Certificate Store

Depending on your Linux distro, you can modify your CA certificate store by taking on an earlier version of your `ca-certificates` package.

For reference, the affected version is [nss 3.63+](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Mozilla/Projects/NSS/NSS_3.63_release_notes). `nss` includes a hard-coded list of trusted CA certificates and therefore can be modified to include and trust the `Verisign Universal Root Certificate Authority` again.

Many Linux distros can leverage `dpkg-reconfigure` to check for the entry and enable trust for it. As a manual workaround, you may need to remove a `leading !` from the certificate line & update your CA certificates package.

**Note:** Doing this is considered a bad security practice & should only be done if you understand the security implications of doing so.

## Solution

Due to existing issues with the .NET 5 signing verification feature & fallback of timestamp verification, we have decided to revoke this feature for Unix-based systems within .NET 5 SDK. Therefore your experience of using `dotnet restore` will remain largely the same as it was in .NET Core 3.1. Stay tuned for an updated .NET SDK version that will include this change.

### Stay updated

- We are continuing to investigate this issue and will let you know more as we find out.
- We will also continue posting updates on [NuGet Status](https://status.nuget.org/) and [@NuGet on Twitter](https://twitter.com/nuget).

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Custom V2 OData queries will be deprecated March 9th, 2021 " (#54) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
We announced the deprecation of custom V2 OData queries (#37) last year and conducted a dry run of the deprecation to ensure that there are no surprises for users (#40). 

We will begin blocking endpoints used by 3rd party clients in March 9, 2021, as detailed in [the blogpost here](https://devblogs.microsoft.com/nuget/custom-v2-odata-queries-will-be-deprecated-march-9-2021/).

Please let us know about your questions or concerns on [this discussion post.](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/7423)

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "The NuGet.org repository signing certificate will be updated as soon as March 15th, 2021" (#53) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
The current NuGet.org repository signing certificate will be updated as soon as March 15th, 2021. If you validate that packages are repository signed by NuGet.org using a [NuGet client policy](https://docs.microsoft.com/nuget/consume-packages/installing-signed-packages), the [`NuGet.exe verify`](https://docs.microsoft.com/nuget/reference/cli-reference/cli-ref-verify) command, or the [`dotnet nuget verify`](https://docs.microsoft.com/dotnet/core/tools/dotnet-nuget-verify) command, you will need to take steps by March 15th, 2021 to avoid disruptions when installing packages from NuGet.org signed with the new certificate. 

If you are unsure if you will be impacted or want to see instructions to allow the new certificate, please see our blogpost on the matter: https://devblogs.microsoft.com/nuget/the-nuget-org-repository-signing-certificate-will-be-updated-as-soon-as-march-15th-2021/
